text.tspan: Natural Language Processing: Theory
Natural language processing (NLP) is a subfield of
linguistics, computer science, and artificial
intelligence concerned with the interactions between
computers and human language, in particular
how to program computers to process and analyze large
amounts of natural language data. The
result is a computer capable of "understanding" the
contents of documents, including the contextual
nuances of the language within them. The technology
can then accurately extract information and
insights contained in the documents as well as categorize
and organize the documents themselves.
NLP Processing Phases
In NLP tasks usually, we can identify the following
phases or tasks:
Language identification, this phase is concerned with
determining the language in which a
text is written.
Tokenization, this phase usually splits the sentence
of characters into meaningful
aggregations, e.g., words, punctuation, symbols, values
and so on.
Stop-word removal, this phase removes therms that
are irrelevant for understanding or
distinguishing a specific text. We want to usually
remove very common and widespread
terms, based on grammar (e.g., articles like
the
or on the specific domain.
Normalization which consists of reporting terms to
a standard form. This can be done
through stemming, which brings the word back to the
root, by suffix stripping; or
lemmatization which brings the word back to its basic
form, but it’s more complicated
because it needs grammatical knowledge.
Indexing and retrieval, which consists in organizing
the documents so as to retrieve those
relevant for a given query.
Part-of-Speech (PoS) tagging, consists in the identification
of the grammatical role of a word
in the context of a phrase or a text.
Parsing consists in determining the sentence structure,
which is usually represented with a
parse Tree.
Text categorization is concerned in determining the
subject of a text, in a pre-defined
taxonomy.
Text understanding, this phase is concerned with understanding
something about the
context and meaning of a text. This can include tasks
of:
Named Entity Recognition (NER) which seeks to locate
and classify named entities
into predefined categories, such as Person, Organization
and so on.
Coreference resolution which finds all expressions
that refer to the same entity in a
text (if the expressions are pronouns we talk about
anaphora resolution).
